content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. The distribution of <math alttext="p H"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> levels for all community swimming pools in a large county is approximately normal with mean 7.5 and standard deviation 0.2. According to swimming pool studies, the safest <math alttext="p H"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> levels for water in swimming pools are between 7.2 and 7.8. (a) One community swimming pool in the county will be selected at random. What is the probability that the selected pool has a <math alttext="p H"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> level that is not considered safe?

The county health inspector will select a random sample of 4 community swimming pools in the county to investigate the <math alttext="p H"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> levels. (b) Describe the sampling distribution of the sample mean for samples of size 4.

(c) Consider the situation in which the health inspector finds the sample mean of the 4 pools to be outside the safe <math alttext="p H"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> levels. As a result, the inspector declares that the population mean is not 7.5. However, if the population mean really is 7.5, the inspector will have made an error. Such an error is called a Type <math alttext="1"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> error. Find the probability that the inspector will make a Type <math alttext="1"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> error with the sample of 4 pools. Show your work.
